articles.title: About this site
articles.description: What is this website and why does it exist?
articles.contents:
This is the personal website for Kyle Conniff. Information about his
research and teaching histories can be found under the similarly labeled
pages. See below for what can be found under each of the pages.

articles.title: Curriculum Vitae
articles.contents:
This is where a CV should be posted for Kyle Conniff. However, the CV
used for grad school applications is currently missing in action (read:
did not look very hard), and does not include very much detail anyways.
Plus, practicing creating new pages is more fun than uploading some
boring sheet anyways. This will be updated later.

articles.title: Home
articles.contents:
I am a Ph.D. student of statistics at the University of California
Irvine (UCI). I am working under the
direction of Dan
Gillen, Ph.D in censored suvival data for Native American health
care. I received a Bachelor’s of Arts from St. Norbert College
(SNC) in mathematics in 2016. I
strive to teach and aid non-statistical faculty in their teaching of
statistical thinking.


Curriculum Vitae



Education:





B.A., in Mathematics, St. Norbert College, De Pere, WI, USA (2016)




Honors and Awards:


National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship Program (2017)


Eugene Cota-Robles Fellowship Recipient (2016)


Diversity Fellowship Recipient (2016)


McNair Scholar (2013)




Certificates:


Course Design Certificate Program (2020)


Wellness at UCI Certificate Program (2020)

articles.title: Who is Kyle Conniff?
articles.description: If you want to know more about Kyle the human, read on!
articles.contents:
Beyond teaching and academics, Kyle has quite a few hobbies that fall
into two big categories: sports and geeks.


Sports



He currently plays professional Ultimate for the
Los Angeles Aviators. As an
undergraduate, he studied abroad in Perth, Australia where he learned
how to play ultimate. Since he was abroad, Kyle spent way too much
getting better at ultimate. After returning to the states, he
immediately tried out for a pro team. It took 3 tries, but he first made
the Aviators in 2019 and has played with them since. To the left is a
photo of Kyle playing in his first Game of the Week in front of an
international audience (PC:
Meg Hofner). This
particular throw ended up making the top plays of the week (well,
technically, the catch made the top plays of the week). The video is
below.





Kyle has also been an active juggler since 2009. His best
friend at the time was one of the world’s best jugglers and they spent
many hours every week working on the ultimate craft for introverts. The
picture to the right (PC:
Casey
Rentmeester) is a classic 5 club cascade (the normal juggling
pattern for an odd number of objects). Before moving to California, Kyle
attended a few juggling conventions annually and even prepared to
participate in a technical juggling competition. Although he didn’t
compete, Kyle trained for 3 hours a day to prepare for competition. At
the time, his personal records are 9 balls, 7 rings, and 6 clubs.
Nowadays, Kyle juggles for about an hour a week split across 3-4 days.
If he juggles with other people, he much prefers to work on passing
patterns (2 or more people juggling together by throwing objects back
and forth) with 6, 7, and 8 clubs, or to play combat with 3 clubs.


Geeks


When Kyle is recovering from his more active endeavors, he watches a lot
of anime. His favorites are old-school: Yu Yu
Hakusho and Rurouni Kenshin. However, he has watched a lot
of good anime and definitely recommends:

Soul Eater


Toradora


Love, Chuunibyou & Other Delusions


My Hero Academia


Seven Deadly Sins.


Sticking with the theme of escapism, Kyle loves to read
science fiction, fantasy, and dystopian future novels in the young adult
genre. He especially loves 3-10 book series where he can feel as though
he has a connection with the main characters. Some of his favorites
include:

The Name of the Wind (by
Patrick
Rothfuss)


The Hunger Games (by
Suzanne Collins)


The Novice (by Taran
Matharu)


Graceling Realm (by
Kristin Cashore)


An Ember in the Ashes (by
Sabaa Tahir)


Kyle’s only vices come from having a bit of a card
collection problem (Yu-Gi-Oh!, Yu Yu Hakusho, Original Pokemon
sets, and original Digimon sets…so far), and playing a relatively small
and selective set of video games. Well, he might also be very addicted
to sugar.


More information to come when Kyle is finally able to adopt the
objectively cutest animal ever (the exact animal is TBD, but it will
undoubtedly be the best and cutest).

articles.title: Research
articles.contents:
My research is currently focused on developing statistical methods for
censored survival data. My research focus is driven by an application to
Native American health care systems and health disparities. My first
dissertation problem is to examine the effect of unknown interval
censoring in recurrent event EHR data under the proportional hazards
assumption and an easy way to reduce bias. The second project is to
develop a prediction model to dealing with unknown interval censoring
when the proportional hazards assumption does not hold. The final
project is to extend the time-dependent AUROC curves to the multivariate
case in order to improve model selection in the prior projects. On the
side, I am (lightly) working on sports analytics for ranking Ultimate
teams and identifying the most useful metrics for predicting the winner
of a game.



Collaborations


Center for American Indian and Alaskan Native Health
(Link)

The center is currently working on understanding dementia in AIAN
populations via two main pathways and two main outcomes. On the
pre-dementia end, the goal is to understand what sociodemographic
factors are associated with onset of dementia and what modifiable risk
factors influence the onset of dementia, with a special emphasis on the
relationship between diabetes and dementia. After developing dementia,
the goal is to understand if (and how) health service utilization
changes, what is most effective, and the resulting costs.

Liberty University Helms School of Government Professor Projects Course

Through a connection with
Dr. Kahlib
Fischer, I worked with class groups to think about organizing and
running quantitative public policy related research projects. Previous
projects I worked with include two different projects on the
relationship between lockdowns and COVID-19 cases in both the United
States and internationally. Another project focused on how voting laws
impact voter fraud. The goal of the course is to introduce students to
research in the field of public policy, but the projects are meant to be
conducted with a potential for presenting and publishing an article
after 2 semesters.



Research Interests


My research interests are primarily driven by the areas of application
and/or in applied directions. Listed below are my main statistical areas
of interest with reasons/applications sub-listed below the topics:

Survival Analysis


Health disparities


Native American health


Health care costs


Electronic health records


Sports Stats


Rankings


Outcome Prediciton


Strategy Development


Strategy Analysis


Player Development


Pedagogy


Remote Teaching


Flipped Classrooms


Using internet resources to improve learning


Developing introductory material for non-stats students taking stats
courses


Developing applications for aiding and teaching students of statistics


Time series


Concussions


Head Trauma


Stress


Neuroimaging


Sleep

articles.title: Teaching
articles.description: Uh oh, this site is under construction.  Please check back after Kyle has done some teaching.
articles.contents:
Teaching Assistant



UCI
COSMOS Exploring the Application of Data Science in the Health
Sciences (July 2021)

Professors: Dr. Mine Dogucu
and Dr. Babak Shahbaba 


This cluster explores how data science can be used to better understand
and treat human health conditions, with the goal of saving lives.



STATS 120A
Introduction to Probability and Statistics I (Summer 2021)

Professor:
Dr. Koko
Gulesserian


Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical
inference. Axiomatic definition of probability, random variables,
probability distributions, expectation.



STATS 7 Basic
Statistics.(Summer 2020)
Professor: Dr. Mary Ryan


Introduces basic inferential statistics including confidence intervals
and hypothesis testing on means and proportions, t-distribution, Chi
Square, regression and correlation. F-distribution and nonparametric
statistics included if time permits.



STATS 7 Basic Statistics (Summer 2018).
Professor:
Dr. Michelle
Nuno



Guest Teaching



Quantitative Methods for Public Policy at Liberty University
(January-March 2021)

Professor:
Dr. Kahlib
Fischer


Working with three project groups to refine their research questions and
hypotheses.



Quantitative Methods for Public Policy at Liberty University (December
2020)

Professor: Dr. Kahlib Fischer


Discussion on the process of performing a statistical analysis.



Quantitative Methods for Public Policy at Liberty University (November
2020)

Professor: Dr. Kahlib Fischer


Discussion on the process of question development and preparing for data
collection.



Teaching



Special Theory Prep (Summer 2021)

Worked with graduate students who failed the first year qualifying exam
in mathematical statistics to improve their foundation in mathematical
statistics and feel prepared for the upcoming school year.



Special Methods and Data Analysis Prep (Summery 2021)

Worked with graduate students who failed the first year qualifying exams
in statistical methods or data analyses to improve their foundation in
methods and preparing a data analysis to feel prepared for the upcoming
school year.





Additional Teaching Endeavors


Kyle has started developing two resources for teaching introductory
statistics. The original ideas and (much appreciated) guidance come from
Dr. Mine Dogucu. The goal is
to turn these projects into useful tools for teaching students the
basics of statistics.

R Package


R Shiny




The two projects currently work together to help students calculate
z-scores, t-scores, quantiles, and p-values from the information that
will be given in a typical introductory question. There is also an
option to visualize the distribution and area to which the probability
corresponds. The projects are only in the very formative stages, with
many more ideas for adding to them. Some of the goals include:

Guide for choosing the right test


Guide for using the right formula


Step-by-step solutions for the z- and t-score questions


Rejection regions on visualization plot


Multiple plots for thinking about conversions from “original units” to
“standard units”


Expanding to two-sample cases


Expanding to other introductory topics


Many more ideas to be sorted through

articles.title: Tutoring
articles.description: Kyle actively tutors in statistics and mathematics.
articles.contents:
Kyle has over 10 years of tutoring experience. He has refined his
1-on-1 tutoring technique to emphasize using the student’s own learning
style to maximize their knowledge base in the subject. Thus, when a
faced with a challenging question, students are prepared to think
through the question in their own terms. If you are looking for an
experienced, personable tutor who will focus on your learning, then
reach out to Kyle by sending him an email:
krconnif@uci.edu.

Current number of students for fall 2021: 4


Student count last updated: 10/172021




Resume


Teaching Assistant: UCI COSMOS: Exploring the Application of
Data Science in the Health Sciences (July, 2021)

Worked with high school students to help them develop insight into how
data science can be used to save and advance human lives. I lead
discussions, answered questions during lectures, graded assignments, and
helped students with an analysis project to end the course.

UCI
COSMOS Cluster 1: Data Science in the Health Sciences




Teaching Assistant: Introduction to Probability and Statistics
I (Summer 2021)

Worked with lecturer to provide remote teaching to students taking a
major-level course in mathematical statistics. I held office hours,
graded assignments and exams, and proctored exams.



Independent Tutor (2012-Current)

I’ve met 1-on-1 with students for several years. I’ve worked completely
independently with students (UCI page below), as well as through
tutoring systems (the second and third links below).

UCI Stats
Department


TakeLessons


Wyzant




Teaching Assistant: Introduction to Statistics  (Summer
2018, Summer 2020)

Worked with the teacher to help teach introductory statistics during the
shortened summer sessions. I taught review sessions, created test
questions, checked homework and lab assignments, and mostly helped
answer student questions about the material, homeworks, and labs.



St. Norbert College Multicultural Center Tutor
(2012-2013)

Similar to holding office hours, I sat in a large room and helped my
multicultural peers with all levels of math from algebra through
multivariate calculus, introductory economics, writing/editing, and a
few other introductory classes I was also taking.



Boy’s & Girl’s Club Tutor (2012-2013)

I helped students at an undisclosed, minority-serving middle school
(6-8th grades) work through all types of math questions.



Ranger Ambassador (2011-2012)

I helped a kindergarten/1st grade teacher with teaching students who
needed a little extra help learn how to add and subtract.



Boy’s & Girl’s Club Program Staff (2009-2016)

I designed and implemented games and activities for teaching and
entertaining children aged 5-18. I primarily worked with children with
no place to go after school on fundamental tasks such as cooking,
homework, and being aware of/respectful to others around them.





Recently Tutored Courses


College Introduction to Statistics


College Pre-calculus


College Algebra


High school Math 3


Pre-calculus


High School AP Calculus A/B


High School AP Calculus B/C


Quantitative Methods in Ecological Sciences


Intermediate Mathematical Statistics


High School AP Statistics


Biostatistics for Nurses


Middle School Algebra


How to teach Statistics for Public Policy


Masters of Teaching Capstone Research Project




Rate


$65/hour for most college and high school level courses.


Rates for children depend on the subjects and expectations of the
parents. Creating lesson plans and teaching subjects will be more
expensive than helping with homework. Please reach out to address
expectations and come to an agreement on hourly rate.


Note: all prices are negotiable. If you explain your situation, I’m sure
we can come to an agreement on an acceptable rate. Students paying for
themselves are typically afforded the most leeway. If you aren’t sure,
just ask. My focus is on student learning, not income.


Second note: I don’t charge for short questions that are texted or
emailed to me. If you have a quick question, send me a pic and I’ll
answer quickly via the same medium. I will recommend a session if I
think it will require a substantial amount of time.




Additional Information

Kyle’s tutoring style may not be entirely typical. He will very
rarely give students the answers to questions. He does not oftentimes
answer students’ questions in his own terms. Instead, he will turn
questions around to the students. He will ask them to return to their
notes and review what the teacher said. He will break the question into
pieces and encourage the student to build up their understanding of the
information as it relates to previously covered material. In essence,
Kyle is a teacher. His focus is on teaching, and tutoring is on
opportunity to be a 1-on-1 teacher.
Tutoring plays a big role in the development of Kyle’s teaching
materials. He has learned a lot about how to not organize a class from
tutoring. He has learned a lot about what topics students struggle with
in various classes. He develops teaching resources based on what would
be most beneficial to his tutees. His goal in teaching is to make each
student feel as though they are being guided through the material by an
individual tutor. And tutoring is one of the methods he practices and
refines the process of achieving this goal.
